My colourful clock

This week I found a really sexy clock on twitter. It uses flash to represent time as a "hexadecimal colour value". I spent a good while staring at this pretty page, trying to decipher how exactly it calculated the colour representation.

Imitation is the sincerest form of flattery (I hope!)

I really liked the way the clock worked and was inspired to see if I could do something similar in the browser. I started out with the trusty HTML5Boilerplate, and got to work playing with converting numbers from decimal to hex and back.

I think Jack's clock converts the hours, minutes and seconds into an approximation of red, green and blue respectively, then tweens between these colours. I decided to make my colours a litte different. I took the number of seconds from the start of the day (12:00 am), converted that into a  hexadecimal number and then added the leading zeros. I added a quick setInterval loop to change the background colour of the body tag every second and animated this change using the jQuery Color plugin.

Modernizr makes HTML5/CSS3 useable

So this got me thinking that a nicer solution for animating the background would be CSS3 transisitions. Modernizr made it really easy to only load the Color plugin when a browser wasn't capable of CSS3 transisitions. I also used it to set the background of the middle box to rgba(), and fall back to a png background image.

Heroku rules!

I've been eyeing up heroku for a long while now itching to test it out. So I wrapped the page up in a sinatra app, committed to git and pushed it to heroku!

So here you have it!

My first Greasemonkey script: BindF5 - liberate your F5 key for most Mac OS X browsers

Like I said in my earlier post the main difficulty I'm currently having with Mac OS X is learning all the keyboard shortcuts. The refresh combo Cmd+R I found to be quite a pain. I write an awful lot of HTML for a living and F5 is definitely the key which is gonna some day wear out on my keyboard. Changing my refresh habit would take a lot of work and heartache! 

So I figured I'd fix it, which as it turns out is really quite easy with a small Greasemonkey script. I uploaded the script to userscripts.org and made an information page, (which honestly took me about twice as long as the script itself). Anyhow, someone might find this useful, and it's a good excuse to start filling out my posterous!

25 Jul 2010

How I like them Apples...

Last weekend I accomplished something, that I have been meaning to do for well over a year, install Mac OS X on my PC. I had tried a fewdifferent methods that never really got very far; thank god for tonymacx86 and his post:

iBoot + MultiBeast: Install Mac OS X on any Intel-based PC.

Turns out it was easier than installing Windows 7. The two drivers missing under OS X were audio and wireless; for which I used VoodooHDA and the Ralink drivers respectively. All in all it’s been a very pleasant experience.

I’ve had quite a lot of differing advice about what’s good and what’s not; so I’m gonna wait before I start shouting about what I like on the platform. The one thing I really need to draw attention to is how different the keyboard shortcuts are!

Some choice shortcuts:

  • Command+Arrow Down to open a file or folder in finder
  • Command+Backspace to delete a file in finder
  • Option+Arrows to navigate words at once in text (think control and arrow key on Windows)
  • Command+Shift+Backspace to clear trash can (I miss my shift+del; proper delete!)
